fields.description:
As a user of the Eucalyptus Management Console I would like to view CloudWatch metrics for my EBS volumes as charts/graphs so that I can determine how those components of my application are performing.

EBS volumes offer the following metrics:

- VolumeReadBytes
- VolumeWriteBytes
- VolumeReadOps
- VolumeWriteOps
- VolumeTotalReadTime
- VolumeTotalWriteTime
- VolumeIdleTime
- VolumeQueueLength

The Volume detail page should offer the following charts (computed from the above metrics):

|| Graph Name || Description Using Raw Metrics ||
|| Read Bandwidth (KiB/s) || Sum(VolumeReadBytes) / 1024 / Period || 
|| Write Bandwidth (KiB/s) || Sum(VolumeWriteBytes) / 1024 / Period || 
|| Read Throughput (Ops/s) || Sum(VolumeReadOps) / Period || 
|| Write Throughput (Ops/s) || Sum(VolumeWriteOps) / Period || 
|| Avg Queue Length (ops) ||  Avg(VolumeQueueLength) ||
|| % Time Spent Idle || Sum(VolumeIdleTime) / Period * 100 || 
|| Avg Read Size (KiB/op) || Avg(VolumeReadBytes) / 1024 || 
|| Avg Write Size (KiB/op) || Avg(VolumeWriteBytes) / 1024 || 
|| Avg Read Latency (ms/op) || Avg(VolumeTotalReadTime) * 1000 || 
|| Avg Write Latency (ms/op) || Avg(VolumeTotalWriteTime) * 1000 ||

The following metrics only apply to Provisioned IOPS (SSD) volumes only and should be considered out of scope for this ticket:

- VolumeThroughputPercentage
- VolumeConsumedReadWriteOps

See http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/monitoring-volume-status.html

NOTES: 
- An EBS volume must explicitly be made available for use within an instance by following the steps detailed at http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/ebs-using-volumes.html in order to trigger CloudWatch metrics for the volume.
- On Eucalyptus, the volume must be attached to an instance with monitoring enabled for the volume to collect CloudWatch metrics.
- On AWS, the volume must be attached to an instance with *detailed* monitoring enabled for the volume to collect CloudWatch metrics.

attachment.filename: Second enable monitoring for instance link.png

comments.body: ok to implement without wireframe

[~jloza]: Rather than displaying charts for raw metrics per se, the AWS Management Console displays charts for volumes as graphs computed from the relevant metrics.  Could you comment if our console should display the same charts as the AWS console, or should we display charts for the raw metrics?

hey [~kgill], should consider rolling up KB to bigger where appropriate, like we did with network? Also, should keep chart names consistent between this and other pages we use them, so if you're using differetn chart names here, please update them on other pages too so they are always the same (i.e. bandwidth vs bytes or size, throughput vs ops etc). I like the more descriptive names you have here, we should just be sure we are consistent across detail pages for the same or similar metrics. Thanks! Nice job!

Also, we should graph the way AWS does, plz.

[~jloza]: The graph names in the table above are specific to volumes, so I don't quite understand what you mean by "should keep chart names consistent between this and other pages...".  

When you mention "we should graph the way AWS does", does that mean you're in favor of using the graph names used by AWS rather than simply graphing raw metrics (e.g. use avg read/write latency instead of volume total read/write time)?

hi [~kgill], we display some similar metrics for instances, like the ones I mentioned around bytes and ops, so we should be consistent with those (if we use something different and more descriptive here, we should update those as well if it makes sense). Check the page or the wireframe and you'll see what I mean. And for the charts, we should display the same as AWS console, please.

[~jloza]: AWS displays the raw metrics for instance charts (see http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/graphs-in-the-aws-management-console.html) so I think we're fine leaving the charts on our Instance Monitoring tab as is.
hi [~kgill], OK, if they aren't the same, we are good then, agreed. Thanks!

[~jloza]: Just wanted to give you an update on this ticket.  I've just about finished implementing the Volume Monitoring page, but I'm still observing some discrepancies between our charts and those on the AWS Console since AWS doesn't clearly document the formulas used for various chart data (i.e. the comment "For the average latency graphs and average size graphs, the average is calculated over the total number of operations...during the period " is a bit vague.  Will keep you posted.

AWS seems to only return the following metric for EBS volumes (see the volume-monitoring- screenshots above):
- VolumeReadOps
- VolumeWriteOps
- VolumeQueueLength
- VolumeIdleTime

While Eucalyptus properly captures the relevant metrics noted in this ticket's description.  Not sure what's going on here, since there's no flag to enable/disable monitoring for EBS volumes, and I performed similar operations on AWS and Euca to generate some data for metrics (i.e. initializing/mounting the volume and downloading a Linux ISO multiple times via wget).  We may want to hide the other charts when logged into AWS in our console if no data is ever returned for those.

[~ethomas]: CloudWatch data for EBS volumes don't seem to be collected unless they are attached to an instance and the instance has monitoring (or detailed monitoring on AWS) enabled.  Could you confirm if that's the case?

/cc [~jloza]

[~ethomas]: I confirmed in the Architecture meeting that volume metrics aren't collected if the instance the volume is attached to has monitoring disabled (on Eucalyptus).  On AWS, the instance must have *detailed* monitoring enabled for volume metrics to be collected.

[~jloza]: Thoughts on how to handle the messaging and enable/disable monitoring feature for volumes with this new info?  If the instance doesn't have monitoring enabled, we should probably provide messaging to that effect and not show any charts on the Volume Monitoring page, similar to how the Instance Monitoring page is handled.  For enabling/disabling monitoring option on the Volume Monitoring page however, perhaps we should display a confirmation dialog that would enable/disable monitoring for the *instance*.  This contrasts with the Instance monitoring enablement behavior on the Instance Monitoring page, which is immediate once the "Turn monitoring on/off" drop-down is selected.

[~kgill], let's add messaging to the monitoring tab in lieu of charts when monitoring (Euca) or detailed monitoring (AWS) is not turned on, and provide a link right there to "turn on <detailed> monitoring for instance <xyz>" that will issue the appropriate call.

[~kgill]Looking at the code in DescribeSensorCallback.java, it appears all cloudwatch data that is returned from the "back end" is instance-centric.  Volume statistics come in as disk statistics about the instance with the volume id being the dimension for the disk stat.  As such, if a volume is not attached to an instance, it does not appear any stats will be returned about it.  I concur with the architecture team.
[~ethomas]: Thanks for confirming.  And to clarify, it appears volume stats are collected only if the volume is attached to an instance with monitoring enabled (detailed monitoring enabled on AWS).

[~kgill] Yes, volume stats are presumably considered to be part of the instance that it is attached to.  Our usage of the "monitoring" flag on an instance is different from AWS.  They still monitor, albeit at 5 minute intervals, if monitoring is disabled, and use 1 minute intervals if monitoring is enabled.  We don't monitor at all if monitoring is disabled (though the metrics still come through, reporting keeps them, as far as I remember), and our monitoring interval if enabled is dependent on a couple of parameters, cloud.monitor.default_poll_interval_ms and cloud.monitor.history_size.
Ready for UX review.  PR is at https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/pull/1751

The volume details "Monitoring" tab page does not include Help text (see "Unattached volume Monitoring tab" attachment). [~tvo], could you please add some Help?

When a volume is not attached to an instance, and the user clicks the "Attach this volume to an instance" link (see "Unattached volume Monitoring tab" attachment), the "Attach volume" dialog window appears (see "Cut off required Instance label" attachment). But (at least in Firefox) the "Instance" label is cut off. If "Instance" is a required field, the "*" is also cut off.

[~kgill], could you please make those fixes? !Unattached volume Monitoring tab.png|thumbnail!  !Cut off required Instance label.png|thumbnail!
[~lnajjar]: Fixes pushed for attach volume to instance dialog, thanks for catching that!  Let's track the help text in a separate ticket to avoid holding this up.  Back to you for UX review.

Submitted GUI-2355 Need Help on New Volume Details "Monitoring" Tab.

Verified on Macintosh running Chrome Version 47.0.2526.106 (64-bit), Firefox 43.0.1, and Safari 9.0.2.

UX review passed. Ready for code review.
I'm seeing 20 API calls being made for graphs when there are only 10 graphs. (not unique to this branch, wrote GUI-2356)

[~lnajjar], I notice when I select "disable monitoring" on the volume monitoring tab, I'm never asked to confirm I want to disable monitoring for the instance it's attached to, and that it has broader effects because it doesn't simply turn off monitoring for this volume only.

I agree with [~dkavanagh] here, and expressed some concerns about turning monitoring on and off at he volume level on the wireframe itself. I think this flow needs to be considered carefully and worked out, so that the user knows exactly what they are doing and controls things at the right spots and as they intend.
Assigning to [~lnajjar] for another UX review following changes noted during today's scrum discussion.

Enable monitoring is now unavailable on this page.

But, oddly, there are two links to turn on monitoring for an attached instance (see attachments). !Second enable monitoring for instance link.png|thumbnail!  !Enable monitoring for instance link.png|thumbnail! 

On the "Enable monitoring for instance link" page, when I click "Enable monitoring for instance i-d992bb1d" I don't enable monitoring for the instance. Instead, I get the "Second enable monitoring for instance link" page. This second page has another link ("Turn on monitoring") to enable monitoring for the instance and it actually turns on monitoring.

I believe we only need the first enable-monitoring-on-the-attached-instance page. Could you please move the functionality of the link on the second page to the link on the first page, then eliminate the second page?

[~lnajjar]: We agreed during yesterday's scrum discussion to make the following changes...
1. Remove the "enable monitoring" option from the Volume Monitoring page, since we don't want to disable instance monitoring from the volume monitoring page
2. Link to the Instance Monitoring page when a volume is attached to an instance that has monitoring disabled.

[~lnajjar]: Got clarification from [~jloza] on how to handle the "Enable monitoring" link on the Volume Monitoring page.  That link is meant to submit the form to enable monitoring of the volume's instance rather than link to the Instance Monitoring page to perform that action.  Guess we took the term "link" too literally here :-)

OK. I updated the wireframe to include that clarification in the description of that link.

So, as described in my comment above, users need to see only one page with a link to enable monitoring of the instance to which the volume is attached, right?

Will you please update the code, then send the ticket back to me for review?

Volume details wireframe: [https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/wiki/display/3UD/Volume+details]

[~lnajjar]: I got the approval from Jenny to convert the "Enable monitoring..." link to a button on the resource monitoring pages, so I'll reassign this to me to implement that on the Volume Monitoring page and the Instance Monitoring page.
Ok, converted "Enable monitoring..." links to buttons.  Back to you for UX review [~lnajjar]
[~lnajjar], as discussed in our 1:1 today, please take a moment to update the wireframes to buttons to match implementation. Shouldn't take much time.

[~kgill], nice improvement for users. Consistent use of buttons to submit "forms." Love it.

Could you please make a couple of minor improvements, please?

On the volume details "Enable monitoring for instance <instance ID>" button label could you please:

1. Use title capitalization to match our other button labels.
2. Also include the instance name (when available) because it is easier for users to recognize and matches the page title

(so "Enable Monitoring for Instance <instance name>(ID)>)


On the instance details "Enable monitoring for this instance" button label could you please:

1. Use title capitalization to match our other button labels.

(so "Enable Monitoring for this Instance")
[~lnajjar]: Suggested fixes implemented for the Enable Monitoring buttons on the Instance and Volume Monitoring pages.  Back to you for UX review

Verified on Macintosh running Chrome Version 47.0.2526.106 (64-bit), Firefox 43.0.2, and Safari 9.0.2.

UX review passed. Ready for code review.
